author: latespoon
content: Debating whether a problem exists, and its extent, is crucial in developing and implementing a solution. We should try to resist the temptation to bury our heads in the sand, especially with an issue as important as this

author: alexssd7fp
content: Yeah, banning everyone who do not agree with your opinion sounds not like the right thing to do.

author: alexssd7fp
content: Plus, all of the latest messages are related only to attacking people skeptical of PoS.

author: postcapone
content:
<@543809401123897352> agreed on your concerns, but unfortunately this is a conversation that is very difficult to create appropriate testing for.

This isn't a technical issue, it is a sociological one.

author: imman6820
content: Did the recent dusting attack that sent 0.01 eth from TC include exchange cold wallets?

author: latespoon
content: Posted in merge public. Quite concerning

author: alexssd7fp
content: Looks like Ethereum has ever-increasing censorship problem that will likely explode post merge (as with PoS you are not allowed to attest to the blocks containing censored transactions, not just producing blocks with them).

author: treyzania
content: of course you're allowed to attest to those blocks

author: treyzania
content: plus, even if that was an issue, attesting to subsequent blocks contributes to the fork choice weight for the subtree so that's fine

author: darius510
content: what percentage need to refuse to attest to it before it becomes problematic? 33% i think?

author: gwintery
content: if they refuse to attest to it, they get inactivity penalty I think, and it gets worse the more people do that

author: gwintery
content: as in the penalty grows quadratically IIRC

author: gwintery
content: looks like PoW isn't the solution either ðŸ¥³

author: darius510
content: I wouldn't draw that conclusion under these circumstances

author: alexssd7fp
content: Why?

author: alexssd7fp
content: We can endlessly discuss about anything but PoW resists censorship significantly better

author: gwintery
content: I think that topic is debated so many times here that we should just agree to disagree

author: darius510
content: Well what I'm saying is that I think you'd see different behavior if we weren't 4 weeks out from the merge, the incentives for miners are flipped right now

author: gwintery
content: it is refreshing to see that a mining pool does censor too, showing that both sides are prone to censorship. and the (possible) lack of change action from miners in that pool probably also tells how much miners care about the network vs their bottom line.

author: gwintery
content: sure that is a valid point

author: latespoon
content: Ethermine aren't going to bother assessing whether they can get away without censoring transactions when they are going out of business next month anyway

author: darius510
content: Bitfly owns ethermine (mining pool) and ethpool (staking pool). They're not going out of business, and they are telegraphing their post-merge behavior.

author: latespoon
content: Great, that's even worse ðŸ˜…

author: gwintery
content: It's good that these actors are brought into the light this early. Censorship resistance was a small itch, but now it becomes increasingly an urgent issue.

They have no right to arrest a person that is innocent and did not commit any crime.

content: that's for the courts to decide
